#Text=Become a Wildlife Rehabilitator
#Text=Wild animals that are hurt or sick need care , just like any other animal .
#Text=Some veterinarians specialize in this kind of work , but the main group of people responsible for healing wild animals are wildlife rehabilitators .
#Text=Becoming a wildlife rehabilitator can take a long time -- you will need to be properly trained and licensed to work with wild animals -- but can be a very rewarding career .
#Text=Steps
#Text=Deciding to Become a Wildlife Rehabilitator
#Text=Get vaccinated .
#Text=Be prepared , because the rehabilitation center will ask you to get certain vaccinations , and provide the paperwork for them .
#Text=A Rabies vaccine is a must .
#Text=Find a center where you can volunteer .

#Text=Search for centers in your area at : http://www.owra.org/find-a-wildlife-rehabilitator If you ca n’t locate any on that site , call your state Game and Wildlife Commission for a list of rehabilitators in your state .
#Text=The " busy season " for wildlife centers starts in the spring .
#Text=This is when baby animals are born , and the boom continues through the summer .
#Text=Most places have limited acceptance periods , so they can have a trained staff on hand for spring .
#Text=Think about volunteering at a couple different places to see which kinds of animals you ’d like to work with .
#Text=Volunteer at a wildlife rehabilitation center .
#Text=Your experience might include doing office work , helping to fundraise , or assisting with some of the animal care .
#Text=At first , you will not be doing much with animals , but you might be helping to prepare food or ready or clean cages or bedding .
#Text=As you get more experience , you might be able to do more hands-on work with the animals .
#Text=You will need to meet these basic criteria before beginning :
#Text=Be 18 or older
#Text=Fill out a volunteer form for the center
#Text=Have enough time to do a shift per week , minimum ( usually 4 hours )
#Text=Participate in annual trainings
#Text=Be willing and able to transport injured animals
#Text=Do an informational interview with a wildlife rehabilitator .
#Text=You might think that you want to train to be a wildlife rehabilitator , but it might be different than you imagine .
#Text=Ask a wildlife rehabilitator if you can interview him or her to get a sense of what they actually do every day .
#Text=Some sample questions might be :
#Text=What does a typical day look like ?
#Text=How did you get into wildlife rehabilitation ?
#Text=What is the most difficult part of your job ?
#Text=What kinds of suggestions do you have for me ?
#Text=Decide where you want to work eventually .
#Text=Do you want to try and get a job at one of the centers where you have volunteered ?
#Text=Talk to them to see if they are planning to hire any time soon .
#Text=Are you planning to do a broad search ?
#Text=You can search internationally here
#Text=Do you want to start your own rehabilitation center ?
#Text=How will you do that ?
#Text=If you want your own center , where will you get the money to purchase and build the facility ?
#Text=Make sure you are prepared for what your job prospects might be .
#Text=Getting Training and Permits
#Text=Get a college degree in biology or ecology .
#Text=Even though for some positions a college degree is not required , it is for most .
#Text=A major in a biology-related field , including coursework on mammalogy , ornithology , animal behavior , and ecology would be the best preparation for becoming a wildlife rehabilitator .
#Text=These courses would give you a background in the way animals function and their environment .
#Text=Approach the head of your facility for an apprenticeship or internship .
#Text=This is a year(or more ) in which your hours are carefully documented and cataloged , followed by a test .
#Text=Most states will require this time period before you are able to be licensed .
#Text=Check with your state ’s Game and Wildlife Department .
#Text=They will have a list of the requirements for becoming a wildlife rehabilitator .
#Text=It ’s common for the list to include specialized training regarding the animals you want to work with , exams to demonstrate proficiency , and possibly participation in a mentorship program .
#Text=Get your license .
#Text=Most states require wildlife rehabilitators to have a license issued by the Game and Wildlife Department .
#Text=Make sure you have all of the qualifications before you apply for the license .
#Text=Some of the requirements may include :
#Text=Veterinarian training , or a period of apprenticeship working in a wildlife rehabilitation center
#Text=Passing a wildlife rehabilitation exam for the species you will deal with
#Text=Completed application
#Text=Working as a Rehabilitator
#Text=Find a job .
#Text=Keep in mind it might take a while , and it might not be full-time .
#Text=You can search one database here for possibilities : http://www.nwrawildlife.org/networking/
#Text=Hopefully you ’ve been able to network and meet enough people during the time you were volunteering and training that you have a group of people in the field that know you .
#Text=Keep up with these people as you look for a job .
#Text=If you want to work at one particular location , keep in contact with them until they have an opening , and always let them know that you are ready to help at any time .
#Text=Work hard rehabilitating wildlife .
#Text=Most wildlife rehabilitators work closely with a veterinarian to care for wild animals in their care .
#Text=As a wildlife rehabilitator , each day is likely to be different as you care for a variety of hurt and sick animals .
#Text=You will be caring for traumatized or wounded animals , new babies whose parents cannot care for them , animals who are disabled in some way , all of whom are wild and undomesticated .
#Text=Each case will require strong knowledge of animal behavior and biology as well as a medical expertise to make a diagnosis and create a treatment plan .
#Text=Keep up with the field .
#Text=Stay in touch with the other people in your network involved in wildlife rehabilitation .
#Text=Take courses to stay current in your licensing .
#Text=Read about the latest innovations and discoveries .
#Text=Think about whether you want to stay in your current position , or if you want to change in the future -- perhaps to open your own center once you ’re an experienced wildlife rehabilitator .
#Text=Quick Summary
